newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta unchanged versus mark, ignores steady rates.
newsitem.headline: Peseta unchanged versus mark, ignores steady rates.

text.p: The peseta showed little reaction to the Bank of Spain's decision to leave interest rates unchanged at 5.25 percent on Tuesday, dealers said.
"After the Bank of Spain's announcement, the mark gained a bit, but the trend suggests the peseta will recover its ground and make further gains," a dealer in Madrid said.
At 0855 GMT, the peseta was trading at 84.25/27 per mark compared with 84.23/25 in early trade and 84.21/22 late on Monday.
Traders said the peseta's strengthening in previous sessions was in line with the mark's weakness versus the U.S. dollar, which was giving European currencies a boost.
"I guess the peseta may aim for 84.10 in the short run," another dealer here said. But he said compared with other European units, the peseta was showing subdued gains.
Against the dollar, the peseta was losing ground, traders said. The dollar was trading at 151.19/24 pesetas on Tuesday versus 150.79/82 late on Monday.
"If the dollar continues its run against the mark, I guess it could go to 155 against the peseta," a dealer said.
